awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrated Modeling and Control of Aftertreatment Systems for Clean, Efficient and High-Performing Gasoline Direct Injection Engines
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project will enable future vehicles to benefit from the improved efficiency and performance of gasoline direct injection (GDI) engines, without suffering from increased soot emissions. An integrated approach is necessary because engine operating conditions determine oxygen and fuel content and temperature of the exhaust gas, which influence the output of the catalytic converter, which in turn governs soot accumulation and oxidation in particulate filters. While the dynamics of diesel engine particulate filters are well understood, particulates produced in GDI engines have substantially different characteristics. Particulate emissions are associated with many adverse health effects, including decreased lung function in both children and adults. As the number of vehicles using GDI engines increases, the need to safeguard public health by mitigating particulate emissions becomes an urgent social concern. Thus this project addresses urgent technological and societal needs. Integration of research and education will be pursued through development of a new graduate course on advanced aftertreatment systems modeling and control, a social media-based discussion group, and a new course for the Clemson Creative Inquiry program. The relationships established in the course of this research will support development of an international research and education program on fundamental modelling and control in exhaust gas aftertreatment systems.

This project will enable new exhaust gas aftertreatment technologies for GDI engines, based on a transformative modeling framework at the intersection of macroscale modeling, numerical simulations and optimization theory. System-level models of the engine, catalytic converter, and gasoline particulate filter will be integrated across length scales, incorporating effects ranging from clogging and regeneration of the filter pores, to continuum gas flow in the exhaust manifold. The framework will enable formulation of low-order models of aftertreament systems suitable for real-time optimization-based control, based on systematic and rigorous reduction of continuum models while maintaining accuracy and fidelity. This project will substantially improve macro-scale representations of soot layer physical properties and pore-scale loading and regeneration phenomena in particulate filters. The results will be used to design physics-based estimators for robust control of advanced aftertreament systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The research presents a significant advancement in the modeling and control of gasoline particulate filters (GPFs) used in gasoline direct injection (GDI) engines, addressing critical challenges in emissions mitigation amid stringent regulatory requirements. By developing pseudo-steady state models, the study offers a computationally efficient alternative to traditional complex multi-physics solvers, enabling real-time monitoring and control of GPF performance. This innovation is crucial for optimizing emissions control strategies in modern automotive applications.

Key contributions of the research include an innovative modeling approach that effectively captures the spatio-temporal dynamics of soot accumulation and filter regeneration processes. This enhances the accuracy and flexibility of GPF models while avoiding the computational burden typically associated with detailed simulations. Additionally, the work proposes a novel pressure drop model to estimate soot accumulation, improving upon existing empirical methods. This new approach facilitates more responsive and adaptive control strategies that can prolong filter life and optimize overall performance.

The environmental impact of this research is substantial, as it focuses on the efficient operation of GPFs, contributing to the broader goals of reducing particulate emissions and supporting the transition to cleaner automotive technologies. This focus is particularly relevant in the context of CO2 mitigation and compliance with emerging emissions standards. Moreover, the findings hold interdisciplinary relevance, impacting automotive engineering, environmental science, and control systems, and fostering collaboration across these fields to tackle pressing environmental challenges. Overall, this research not only enhances the understanding of GPF dynamics but also provides practical tools for improving the sustainability of GDI engines, making it a valuable contribution to the field.


Last Modified: 10/25/2024
Modified by: Simona Onori
